content: I'm gonna turn this Power Rangers toy from the dollar store into something
cool for tabletop gaming or the very least I'm gonna try hey guys welcome
back to the black magic craft this week doing what is many of yours favorite
type of video a dollar store challenge I know it's not everybody's favorite but
they sure are popular and they are fun to do last night I went to the dollar
store in the hopes of finding something inspiring and cool and I went to one of
the smaller ones the closest one to my house and you notice there wasn't a lot
that really piqued my interest but I saw this it's a little red Power Ranger
figure and the pose was pretty interesting and I can absolutely
visualize this as some sort of really cool statue monument for any kind of
game D&D frost grave whatever yeah turning things into statues is kind of a
cop-out but I have some ideas to really kind of push this to make it look neat
and the thing is statues and monuments are really really useful bits of scatter
train for almost every game and I don't have enough of them so that's what we're
gonna do wish me luck first thing I need to do is assess what
I have to work with okay so we got the figure which looks
pretty good and I'm just gonna cut them away from the base right now this
actually could be kind of useful and it might look good on a wall or a tile or
something like that but it might be a super recognizable power ranger symbol
and if that's the case I don't want to use it which I'm assuming it is I don't
know much about Power Rangers haven't watched Power Rangers since about I
don't know 1998 maybe I think we're gonna scrap all of this and focus on
this dude there's a couple features on here that I think I immediately want to
remove this gun in the whole surfer example because that's just way too
modern and I think this is gonna end up being a sort of fantasy type figure so
we're gonna cut away this gun and holster it's pretty soft plastic so it's
not too hard to do and since my intent is to turn this into a sculpture just
doesn't have to be as nice as if it was gonna be a playable character figure
which it's too big for anyway I think I want this guy to have a cape so I figure
out how I'm gonna do that there's a couple different methods I could use all
of them have varying amounts of annoyingness and waiting time let's see
what I got green stuff and milla pot I often prefer to work with milliput
because it's a little bit softer and can be easily smoothed with water or
something like a cave I want it to have some rigidity and be able to roll out a
flat thin piece so green stuff is probably gonna be better fortunately I
will have to wait for it to cure which kind of sucks but I think everything I
do I'm gonna have to wait for it to cure I could also sculpt this out of like
toilet paper and glue or paper towel in glue that will take even longer to dry
then this stuff green stuff is all mixed up I also went and gave this guy a quick
wash in warm soapy water make sure there was no mold release or
grease on him from the factory now I got to turn this green stuff into a cape and
I've never done anything quite like this before I've used green stuff to sculpt
some things nothing like this I can already tell that that's gonna stick too
much to this tile ah so I'm gonna use a little bit of this sculptors Vaseline on
the tile a little bit on the rolling pin now I might be doing this completely
wrong this is certainly not my area of expertise but I learned through doing
the Vaseline just makes this spin no boy have a mini sculptor do this crap as too
slippery past a roller would be awesome for this every time I've done projects
like this where I've messed around with green stuff to actually sculpt something
usually ends up taking me a few tries now that I have that apps which is
probably covered in fingerprints that will transfer my part that I really
don't like it's right on the hood I've kind of squished it a fair amount it
looks strange see if I can fix this I feel like this guy would look way
cooler if he had a skeletal face and was more like a badass Lich don't
particularly want to sculpt a face so I'm just gonna look through these random
minis to see if I have a kind of skeleton face that would be about the
right size it's gonna be tricky because this guy is bigger than 28 millimeters
so I don't know if I'll actually have anything in there no don't got anything
that is quite right [Applause]
this is the part of the video where I remember that I have a big box of
citadel skulls it's got to be something in here gotta be something in here
these are all too small I don't want like an orc skull probably too big those
are all gonna be their own scale obviously this one right here might work
it's a little bit too big but it might work it might be kind of comically large
but that's better than small because then it could look like a mask also this
one is concave and since this figure already has a head and I haven't cut it
off yet this will be easier to apply them say a solid skull obviously this
would have been better to do before doing the green stuff I don't know a
little goofy if I can get it to sit further back on his face it'll be okay I
need to hollow it out a bit green stuff Citadel skulls rotary tools we have long
since left the area of dollar-store sue me
alright boy do I ever wish I did this
before the green stuff Cape should he have some horns feel like you should
have some horns think I'm gonna create another layer of green stuff for his
cowl just to make it all blend in a little bit better
anybody who has sculpted a lot of miniatures and got a green stuff that's
watching this is probably really totally laughing at me right now for doing
everything so stupidly not great we're getting there not quite having the
effect that I had hoped for I mean what was getting more and more screwed up I
don't know I think I think that's not working we got to start again
pretty okay with how it looks on his face I thought this would be so much
easier to do sculpting a cape should not be this hard I'm doing a lot of things
wrong apparently but it helped if I attach this to something more secure and
solid said to this slippery tile I feel like this is going poorly no no this is
not what I was hoping for I'm fighting against the exaggerated oversized skull
on this thing it really just makes the whole thing look a bit goofy and that's
really not helping and I'm trying to fix it with this cape that I'm not very good
at sculpting and overall this is not going well look more like
hair with maybe instead of a Lich with a flowing cape this thing looks more like
a tribal chieftain warrior and maybe he's wearing like something akin to a
buffalo skull because I can sculpt this to look like a mane of animal hair maybe
this will be more appropriate and easier to do that would also justify the
oversized skull now this is going much better I think I'm gonna give them like
a loincloth or something instead but the skull here I just I think it's too big
and goofy looking and I'm thinking of switching it out for that one just a
straight-up animal skull and it might look better what's that my thought is
that this will look more like a mask on the face rather than that other one that
just looked like he had a really big head
I've also glued this to a real solid handle so that I can work on sculpting
this without touching the green stuff now let's work on some kind of loincloth
and I'm gonna try using this it's one of the green stuff world sculpting tools
it's a texture print meant for fur alright
good sign now let's do a little shoulder
shawl thing
I think I've managed to salvage this project it was not going very well for
me and I certainly did not end up where I plan to be but sometimes if things are
going bad you got to just take a step back let the material lead you pivot and
try something different sure this isn't the you know robed
wizard that I initially planned but he's a cool looking tribal sorcerer and
that's alright I gotta keep moving on this project though I got to be
time-efficient here and this green stuff is gonna take a couple hours to cure
before I can mess with it so I'm gonna move on to the base and originally my
plan was to put this on some sort of styrofoam pillar or something like that
but I glued it to this medicine container to keep it stable and realize
that right here it's already on a pretty great base it's strong it's glued so
there's no sense messing with that but just leaving like that would be kind of
boring and I was again they came up building it up on a pillar or something
then I realized that on this lid there's this spinning plastic thing this
mechanism that makes it connect and I had what I think is a brilliant idea I
found a big plastic miniature base that is larger than this I realized that if I
were to attach this to the base and only glue this ring leaving this separate I
would be able to spin this figure on the base the DMS in the room are already
thinking what I'm thinking this can turn into a really cool interactive puzzle
piece I will put some sort of indicator on the front of this and then maybe
carve a series of rooms on this thing and it will work almost like a
combination lock and be pretty cool again probably would have worked better
if this was a robed sort of wizard but hey I just go with some really
archaic tribal runes it'll work out pretty cool so how am I going to do that
this is a thin plastic I could use some more green stuff and roll it out and put
on there and carve the runes in maybe some Milla pot I could just try to
scratch them into this I don't think that'll work well I think I'm going to
roll up some milliput and carve them in that way
now should be able to just imprint this
and create a little groove for this to sit in just a matter of getting it
centered that's good
I just need something to be the waypoint on this and I don't see any reason to
not turn back toward my citadel skulls the amount of mileage I've gotten out of
this little box of skulls is absolutely absurd one of the best purchases I have
ever made I can start thinking about weapons this is pretty awesome when
doing a kind of kit bash mix mash half sculpted kind of mess of a project like
this it's always incredibly satisfying to hit it with the black primer it ties
it all together and it makes you realize that a lot of the stuff you're doing
that you thought might look like crap actually looks pretty damn decent I've
officially decided that I am going to paint this like a patina
bronze statue and to do that I'm gonna use some model air colors through my
airbrush and I'm doing this because well one airbrushing is a little bit easier
and you can put it on thinner but also because a lot of these little tiny thin
flaps of green stuff they're pretty delicate and I don't want to be hitting
it too hard with a brush that being said you can absolutely get away with
painting statues like this without an airbrush and just use cheap craft paint
and a paint brush and if you don't believe me I will put a link up there to
a video where I did a whole bunch of miniatures doing just that with much
simpler cheaper materials another reason an airbrush is gonna be super handy for
this one is that this thing it spins so it'd be pretty annoying to do it with
the paintbrush at least with the airbrush it won't be pushing it around
before I paint it out with the metallic color I'm gonna undercoat it with this
orangie Brown to give the metallic some help and so that I don't need to use as
much of the metallic
this guy is looking pretty damn nifty
I'm really happy with the way it looks the figure looks great hi I'm so in love
with this idea of it spinning on the rooms the only thing I don't really like
seeing it painted is that I didn't do anything to this lid to make it look
different because I thought you know having it smooth in this these little
line pattern here would look good but it does really kind of look just like a lid
which I don't like but I don't think it's worth going in and changing at this
point if I were to do this again I would probably add some kind of banding around
this to make it look less like a pill bottle lid now there's two approaches I
could take with this in terms of the washes if I wanted this to stay looking
very regal and shiny and new I would go in with a flush shade wash this sort of
reddish wash over a gold or a bronze makes things look really rich and
awesome but I want this thing to look really old and tarnished and a bit
creepier because I mean look at look at the figure just it should be creepier so
I am going to use a black wash and a vert agrees kind of patina on it to make
it look like old bronze I painted this using craft paint and a homemade black
wash and my homemade patina wash and you can absolutely get great result doing
that but this time around on this one I'm gonna see if using a real
off-the-shelf black wash is better and also if this GW or Citadel patina gives
me a better effect again you don't have to you can use homemade stuff but as you
can see I'm basically out of it and I bought this bottle to try so we're gonna
see how it compares
overall paint job turned out pretty decent I did end up also using a brown
wash after the black one just because I thought the gold the color was still too
bright and I wanted to take it a little bit closer towards bronze I will say
that this Citadel stuff is really good and it definitely is a lot stronger and
in a sense works a lot better than the homemade stuff that I use however it's
definitely designed to be used sparingly in details with care on a miniature and
I'd like to just drench a thing in it and be done with it and kind of patina
the whole thing and in that sense this was too thick and it probably would have
been better to have thinned is a bit or just used my homemade watch but I think
I'll probably save this for just actual details on minis versus big statues like
this in the future I finished it off by giving everything a dry brush with this
bright gold just to come back and bring some of the highlights back onto it
places big raised smooth spots where the patina may be worn off I think it really
helps the look this pill cap again was a bit of a problem it was really hard to
get this looking good so you know I tried different things splotching it
with toilet paper paper towel brush and kind of got it okay but in retrospect
the one thing I would change about this build if I were to do it again is I
would have decorated this to look more like a carved maybe stone platform
something with more texture that was a little bit easier to paint and well a
little less pill bottle looking but man I'm still just really happy with the
cleverness of this let's get some fancy photos
so what do you guys think let me know in
the comments personally I think it's pretty damn nifty what started as a
Power Ranger toy ended up as a very useable bit of fantasy terrain that is
gonna work perfectly for D&D the paint job could definitely be improved but the
coolness of the spinning bass makes up for that in my opinion tackling projects
like this does require some special tools and if you're thinking of giving
the hobby ago and want some more info on what tools to buy check out my essential
equipment page on black magic craft CA there I have a list of most of the stuff
I use with explanations as to why I also have links to where you can buy the
exact items on Amazon those are affiliate links and purchasing through
them earns the channel a commission that helps fund the production of videos like
this these videos are a huge undertaking to produce each week and the only reason
I'm able to do it is because of the support from viewers on patreon throwing
the channel a couple of bucks a month is monumental and it lets me focus on doing
what I do without embedding a bunch of off-topic sponsor ads in my videos by
signing up you get access to some cool rewards like the private fellowship
Facebook group and the new discord server I really hope you found this
video inspirational and informative and if nothing else entertaining hit the
like button if you did drop me a comment below and if you're new around here
don't forget to hit subscribe I put videos like this up each and every
Friday cheers everyone have yourself a great weekend
